content.webTitle: Indonesia should be wary of Cameron's head-patting | Deborah Orr

fields.headline: Indonesia should be wary of Cameron's head-patting
fields.bodyText: It was notable that Tony Blair tired quickly of domestic politics, and turned his attention to "the world stage", with results that were unfortunate, to say the least. David Cameron took even less time to "go international", and the heart sinks to hear him lecturing about Islam and democracy in the way that Blair did. Cameron's head-patting of Indonesia, as a state that "gets it right" is clearly directed at a western, not a Muslim, audience. He should think hard, though, about the effect his words may have on the people he is most concerned about discouraging – extremists, for whom western approval is a sign of decadence. Indonesia's success, and the choices its people make, have nothing to do with Cameron. He may wish to be burnished by association. For Indonesia though, there's a danger that his enthusiastic endorsement will be viewed in dangerous quarters as a smear and a taint.
